photo.title: The Khufu Boat

photo.description: The Khufu Boat Museum at the Giza pyramid complex (Picture shows Parts of the first boat like it been found in the the eastern pit ) Kari Timo Steffen, Ph.D. in Microbiolgy University of Helsinki, Member of Finnish Egyptological Society since 2008 included in the case explained: The Khufu boat has been on display to the public in a specially built museum at the Giza pyramid complex since 1982 but not without complications. It has been kept in poorly managed conditions. The boat museum's environment and tourist visitation procedures have already done their own, since the vessel had already been adversely affected by direct and indirect damage from humidity, temperature fluctuation, light and pollution. Also biological degradation, partly already of ancient origin, is visible all over the ship. There is an urgent need to evaluate the current state of this ship and find new solutions for its conservation including relocation to another museum. Our team is planning to determine the strength of the hull with an ultrasound technique. In a second meeting with Dr. Hawass and the Japanese team lead by Prof. Yoshimura details about a possible excavation of the second Khufu boat were discussed. This meeting included a field visit with members of the Supreme Council of Antiquities to view the progress of securing the area around the boat pit including the set up of a new protective hangar. One of the most important things that we are doing together with Dr. Sakuji Yoshimura at the moment is the restoration of the second solar boat of Khufu, which has remained in its boat pit, sealed away, until now. In 1987 National Geographic inserted a camera into the pit, and it showed that there were insects damaging the wood. After that, Yoshimura raised the funds from the Japanese government, and killed these insects in order to save the boat. Now he has placed a camera inside the boat pit so that people visiting Giza can see the boat inside. It is a major undertaking to restore this boat, and it will be one of the best projects in conservation history, said Secretary General of the Supreme Council for Antiquities Dr. Zahi Hawwas.

photo.description: The Khufu Boat Museum next to the Great Pyramid at the Giza pyramid complex is one of the places you "must view" like the sphinx and the pyramids themselves. It housed in a climate controlled space the remains of the most spectacular of all Egyptian boats found to date.
photo.tags: egypt giza khufuship cheops cheopssolarboat 2011 cheopsboat cheopsboatmuseum khufuboatpits khufuboatmuseum solarboat solarbarque royalshipofkingcheops ancientboat gizaplateau ancientritualvessel greatpyramid سفينةخوفو مراكبالشمس barcafunerariadekeops barcasolar granpirámidedeguiza barcasolaredicheope barquesolaire khéops grandepyramide muséedelabarquesolaire
photo.title: The Khufu Boat

photo.description: The Khufu Boat Museum at the Giza pyramid complex There are three main schools of thought concerning the function of Khufu's boats.(There is another boat still waits for its recovery) The first, propounded by Jaroslav Cerny, is that four of them were ritual boats for carrying the king to the four cardinal points and that the fifth was the boat in which the body of the king was transported to Giza. The second school, originally expressed by Walter Emery in reference to the first-dynasty mastaba at Saqqara and then adopted by Egyptologist Selim Hassan, holds that they were solar boats and thus carried the king to visit the sun god Re, or accompanied him in his voyage across the sky. The third concept, expounded principally by Abdel-Moneim Abu Bakr, suggests that all the boats were originally used in the king's lifetime for pilgrimages and other ceremonies. Some Egyptologists argue that Khufu's boats may have touched water, pointing to rope marks on the wood that could have been caused by the rope becoming wet and then shrinking as it dried. However, Hawass believes that these were symbolic vessels, not funerary boats, and were not used to bring Khufu's embalmed remains up the Nile from the ancient capital of Memphis for burial in the Great Pyramid, the oldest and largest of Giza's Pyramids. He says solar symbols found inside the second pit offer more evidence that those who disassembled and buried the boats believed Khufu's soul would travel from his tomb in the pyramid through a connecting air shaft to the boat chambers, and that he would use the boats to circle the heavens, like the sun god, taking one boat by day and the other by night. According to Egyptologist John Darnell of Yale University, new research into the second boat could fill in some blanks about the significance of the vessels and help determine whether they ever actually plied River Nile waterways or were of purely spiritual importance. "In Egypt, almost everything real had its counterpart meaning or significance in the spiritual world. But there's a lot of debate as to whether these vessels were ever used or not," Darnell said. text by Nevine El-Aref, © Copyright Al-Ahram Weekly. All rights reserved
photo.tags: cheopsboat cheopsboatmuseum khufuship khufuboatpits khufuboatmuseum solarboat solarbarque cheopssolarboat royalshipofkingcheops ancientboat gizaplateau ancientritualvessel greatpyramid سفينةخوفو مراكبالشمس barcafunerariadekeops barcasolar granpirámidedeguiza barcasolaredicheope barquesolaire khéops grandepyramide muséedelabarquesolaire egypt giza thekhufuboat cheops
photo.title: The Khufu Boat

photo.description: The Khufu Boat Museum at the Giza pyramid complex The boat's prow and stern are in the form of papyrus stalks, with the one on the stern bent over. It is therefore essentially a replica of a type of papyrus reed boat, perhaps dating back to the predynastic period. It is not difficult to find many objects of a similar style made in the Old Kingdom in more durable material. It has a cabin or inner shrine, which is enclosed within a reed-mat structure with poles in the same papyrus type. It also has a small forward cabin that was probably for the captain. Propulsion was by means of 10 oars, and it was steered using two large oar rudders located in the stern. There was no mast and therefore no sail, and the general design of the boat would have not allowed it to be used other than for river travel. text by Nevine El-Aref, © Copyright Al-Ahram Weekly. All rights reserved

photo.description: The Great Pyramid of Giza (also known as the Pyramid of Khufu or the Pyramid of Cheops) is the oldest and largest of the three pyramids in the Giza Necropolis bordering what is now El Giza, Egypt. It is the oldest of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World, and the only one to remain largely intact. Egyptologists believe that the pyramid was built as a tomb for fourth dynasty Egyptian Pharaoh Khufu (Cheops in Greek) over a 10 to 20-year period concluding around 2560 BCE. Initially at 146.5 metres (481 feet), the Great Pyramid was the tallest man-made structure in the world for over 3,800 years.

Egyptologists believe that the pyramid was built as a tomb for fourth dynasty Egyptian Pharaoh Khufu (Cheops in Greek) over a 10 to 20-year period concluding around 2560 BCE. photo.title: Esfinge y Keops

photo.description: The Great Sphinx is located in Egypt on the Giza (Gizeh) plateau, situated about six miles west of Cairo. It is near a trio of large pyramids (Great Pyramid of Khufu (Cheops), Khafre (Chephren) and Menkaura (Mycerinus)). Giza is a rich archaeological site which also contains the smaller Queen's pyramids, temples, causeways, and numerous rectangular tombs (mastabas) for attendants and other family members.
photo.title: The Great Sphinx and the Great Pyramid of Giza (Giza, Egypt)

photo.title: Giza Plateau - Great Pyramid

photo.description: After ascending through the initial 4 ft. high tunnel, you enter the Grand Gallery which is 28 feet high. Finally a chance to stand up! The climb continues into to the King's Chamber. I don't have any pictures of the King's Chamber because there was someone in there and we weren't supposed to have any cameras inside the pyramid in the first place!
photo.title: Giza Plateau - Great Pyramid

photo.description: Another view from the northwest corner of the Great Pyramid.
photo.title: Giza Plateau - Great Pyramid
Panoramic View Of Cairo From The Great Pyramid of Giza

photo.description: Five boat pits are sunk around the Great Pyramid built in the 26th century BCE. One was opened in 1954. A 43-meter-long boat was rebuilt from the 1200 pieces of wood found inside. It is displayed in a pavilion adjacent to the Great Pyramid suspended above the pit where it was found. Archeologists call them 'solar boats,' but their purpose is uncertain. On Google Earth: The Great Pyramid 29°58'44.69"N, 31° 8'4.75"E

photo.description: For about 10 to 20 dollars you can ride a camel across the desert to the west of the pyramids. It unexpectedly proved rather worthwhile since it provides a better view of all the pyramids and is more isolated from the many tourists.
photo.tags: greatpyramidsofgiza giza pyramid cairo egypt pyramidofkhufu pyramidofcheops cheops khufu camel
photo.title: Great Pyramids of Giza

photo.description: A view of the Pyramid of Khafre from the mortuary temple. It is larger than previous temples and is the first to include all five standard elements of later mortuary temples: an entrance hall, a columned court, five niches for statues of the pharaoh, five storage chambers, and an inner sanctuary. The temple was built of megalithic blocks but, as you can see, it is now largely in ruins.
photo.tags: greatpyramidsofgiza giza pyramid cairo egypt pyramidofkhufu pyramidofcheops cheops khufu
photo.title: Great Pyramids of Giza

photo.title: P1000549

photo.description: [img069-06A-x] "The Great Pyramid of Giza is the oldest and largest of the three pyramids in the Giza Necropolis bordering what is now El Giza, Egypt. It is the oldest of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World, and the only one to remain largely intact. Egyptologists believe that the pyramid was built as a tomb for fourth dynasty Egyptian Pharaoh Khufu (Cheops in Greek) over an approximately 20 year period concluding around 2560 BC. Initially at 146.5 metres (480.6 ft), the Great Pyramid was the tallest man-made structure in the world for over 3,800 years, the longest period of time ever held for such a record." [Wikipedia (unknown date). Great Pyramid of Giza. (consulted (2011)] This photo also appears on Panoramio

photo.title: Beetle Pyramid at Giza

photo.description: The sphinx and the pyramids. The scientist say that up to 100 000 men worked for 20years to build one of these great pyramids. And they were'nt slaves, they got paid for their work!

photo.title: Sphinx & Pyramids

photo.description: We had lunch in the lovely Khan El Khalili Restaurant in the Mena House Oberoi Hotel which has a view of the Great Pyramid that would be enhanced by cutting down the large shrub in front of the window. I had an Indian dish, Murgh Makhi (a spicy chicken curry). Desert was a flan. On Google Earth: Mena House Oberoi Hotel 29°59'2.73"N, 31° 7'59.04"E The Great Pyramid 29°58'44.69"N, 31° 8'4.75"E
photo.title: 20111104_Egypt_1161+62+64+65 Giza Mena House lunch

photo.description: A close-up and post-processed view of the base of the Pyramid of Khafre. Great Pyramid in the background.
photo.title: Giza Plateau - Pyramid of Khafre

photo.description: Me in front of the Sphinx with the Great Pyramid in the background. On Google Earth: The Sphinx 29°58'31.01"N, 31° 8'15.20"E The Great Pyramid 29°58'44.69"N, 31° 8'4.75"E
photo.title: 20111104_Egypt_1245 Giza Sphinx
